questions.question: What role does a write blocker play when acquiring digital evidence?

choices.a: It ensures the data remains intact and unaltered during acquisition.
choices.b: It erases the data on the evidence device to prevent contamination.
choices.c: It decrypts encrypted data on the evidence device.
choices.d: It accelerates the acquisition process by skipping certain data segments.

questions.question: What potential risk can be mitigated by using a write blocker during forensic analysis?

choices.a: Loss of critical data due to accidental deletion.
choices.b: Unauthorized access to confidential files.
choices.c: Modification or contamination of evidence data.
choices.d: Inability to analyze the metadata of files.

questions.question: Which type of devices can benefit from the use of write blockers?

choices.a: Only hard drives and SSDs.
choices.b: Only network devices.
choices.c: Only smartphones and tablets.
choices.d: Any device with storage media, including hard drives, flash drives, and memory cards.

432.definition: (work recovery time) In disaster recovery, time additional to the RTO of individual systems to perform reintegration and testing of a restored or upgraded system following an event.

questions.question: What does Work Recovery Time (WRT) measure in the context of business continuity?

choices.a: The time it takes to restore data from backups.
choices.b: The time it takes to recover business operations after a disruption.
choices.c: The time it takes to assess the impact of a disaster.
choices.d: The time it takes to perform regular data backups.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Work Recovery Time Objective (RTO)?

choices.a: The maximum allowable time for data restoration.
choices.b: The time needed to resume normal operations after a disaster.
choices.c: The time it takes to identify a business continuity event.
choices.d: The time it takes to prepare and implement a disaster recovery plan.

questions.question: In a disaster recovery plan, what factors can influence the determination of Work Recovery Time?

choices.a: The availability of skilled personnel.
choices.b: The size and complexity of the organization.
choices.c: The location of the primary data center.
choices.d: The frequency of backup operations.

questions.question: What does a shorter Work Recovery Time imply in terms of business continuity?

choices.a: Higher costs associated with recovery efforts.
choices.b: Minimal disruption to business operations.
choices.c: Lower priority for disaster recovery planning.
choices.d: Reduced need for off-site data storage.

questions.question: Which business function is most critical to consider when determining Work Recovery Time?

choices.a: Non-essential administrative tasks.
choices.b: Routine maintenance activities.
choices.c: Revenue-generating activities.
choices.d: Employee training programs.

433.definition: (eXtensible Markup Language) A system for structuring documents so that they are human- and machine-readable. Information within the document is placed within tags, which describe how information within the document is structured.

questions.question: What does XML stand for?

choices.a: eXtensible Markup Language
choices.b: Extra Modular Language
choices.c: Xerox Markup Language
choices.d: Extended Model Language

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of XML?

choices.a: To format web pages for display in browsers.
choices.b: To enable communication between hardware devices.
choices.c: To describe the structure and content of data.
choices.d: To create interactive user interfaces.

questions.question: Which tag is used to define the root element of an XML document?

choices.a: <xml>
choices.b: <root>
choices.c: <element>
choices.d: <document>

questions.question: What is the purpose of a DTD (Document Type Definition) in XML?

choices.a: To specify the layout and design of a web page.
choices.b: To provide encryption for XML data.
choices.c: To define the structure and valid elements of an XML document.
choices.d: To create dynamic content in XML documents.

questions.question: In XML, what is the purpose of attributes within elements?

choices.a: To define the content of the element.
choices.b: To provide a unique identifier for the element.
choices.c: To create nested elements within the current element.
choices.d: To store metadata or additional information about the element.

434.definition: Attack method where malicious XML is passed as input to exploit a vulnerability in the target app.

questions.question: What is XML injection?

choices.a: A technique to modify database records using XML files.
choices.b: A method to inject malicious code into XML documents.
choices.c: A way to enhance XML documents with inline JavaScript code.
choices.d: A process to extract sensitive information from XML-encoded files.

questions.question: Which of the following is a potential consequence of successful XML injection?

choices.a: Changing the color scheme of a web page.
choices.b: Executing arbitrary code on the server.
choices.c: Adding decorative images to an XML document.
choices.d: Creating hyperlinks within XML data.

questions.question: How can XML injection vulnerabilities be mitigated?

choices.a: By avoiding the use of XML in web applications.
choices.b: By using complex XML schemas.
choices.c: By disabling JavaScript in browsers.
choices.d: By properly validating and sanitizing user input.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an XML injection attack?

choices.a: Modifying a web page's font size.
choices.b: Changing the order of items in a shopping cart.
choices.c: Injecting malicious code into an XML-based API request.
choices.d: Displaying a popup window on a website.

questions.question: What is a common way for attackers to exploit XML injection vulnerabilities?

choices.a: Sending unsolicited email messages.
choices.b: Guessing weak passwords.
choices.c: Submitting excessively long input.
choices.d: Using social engineering techniques.

435.definition: (cross-site request forgery) A malicious script hosted on the attacker’s site that can exploit a session started on another site in the same browser.

questions.question: What is Cross-Site Request Forgery (XSRF) also known as?

choices.a: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
choices.b: SQL Injection
choices.c: Clickjacking
choices.d: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) Attack

questions.question: What is the main objective of a Cross-Site Request Forgery (XSRF) attack?

choices.a: Stealing sensitive data stored in the database.
choices.b: Modifying the appearance of a website.
choices.c: Gaining unauthorized access to a system.
choices.d: Executing actions on behalf of a victim user without their consent.

questions.question: How does Cross-Site Request Forgery (XSRF) typically occur?

choices.a: By exploiting vulnerabilities in server software.
choices.b: By injecting malicious code into web forms.
choices.c: By tricking users into unknowingly executing unauthorized actions.
choices.d: By launching brute force attacks against login pages.

questions.question: Which of the following measures can help prevent Cross-Site Request Forgery (XSRF) attacks?

choices.a: Implementing strong encryption for user passwords.
choices.b: Disabling JavaScript on web pages.
choices.c: Validating and sanitizing user input.
choices.d: Using anti-CSRF tokens in forms.

questions.question: In a Cross-Site Request Forgery (XSRF) attack, what role does the victim play?

choices.a: The victim initiates the attack.
choices.b: The victim unknowingly performs actions without their consent.
choices.c: The victim hacks into the attacker's system.
choices.d: The victim intercepts communication between the attacker and the target.

436.definition: (cross-site scripting) A malicious script hosted on the attacker’s site or coded in a link injected onto a trusted site designed to compromise clients browsing the trusted site, circumventing the browser’s security model of trusted zones.

questions.question: What is Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)?

choices.a: A type of denial-of-service attack.
choices.b: A technique for exploiting SQL vulnerabilities.
choices.c: A way to perform man-in-the-middle attacks.
choices.d: A vulnerability that allows executing malicious scripts in a user's browser.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a reflected Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attack?

choices.a: Modifying the content of a database.
choices.b: Sending malicious emails to users.
choices.c: Injecting malicious scripts through input fields.
choices.d: Stealing sensitive data from a server.

questions.question: How does an attacker typically deliver a stored Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attack?

choices.a: By exploiting vulnerabilities in server software.
choices.b: By tricking users into clicking on malicious links.
choices.c: By intercepting communication between client and server.
choices.d: By physically gaining access to the target's system.

questions.question: What type of user input is often used to exploit Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) vulnerabilities?

choices.a: Numeric values.
choices.b: Binary files.
choices.c: HTML tags or JavaScript code.
choices.d: Special characters for authentication.

questions.question: How can web developers mitigate the risk of Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks?

choices.a: Installing antivirus software on the server.
choices.b: Using weak passwords for admin accounts.
choices.c: Implementing input validation and output encoding.
choices.d: Disabling encryption for web communication.

437.definition: (Zed Attack Proxy) An open-source interception proxy and web application assessment tool.

questions.question: What is OWASP ZAP?

choices.a: A cybersecurity certification organization.
choices.b: A popular web application firewall.
choices.c: A free and open-source security testing tool.
choices.d: A technique for encrypting network traffic.

questions.question: What is the main purpose of OWASP ZAP?

choices.a: To automate web application deployment.
choices.b: To provide real-time analytics for websites.
choices.c: To simulate distributed denial-of-service attacks.
choices.d: To help find security vulnerabilities in web applications.

questions.question: Which of the following is a key feature of OWASP ZAP?

choices.a: Generating synthetic user traffic.
choices.b: Blocking network attacks.
choices.c: Analyzing physical hardware vulnerabilities.
choices.d: Spidering and scanning web applications.

questions.question: How does OWASP ZAP assist in finding security vulnerabilities?

choices.a: By disguising network traffic to bypass firewalls.
choices.b: By providing secure authentication for web applications.
choices.c: By simulating social engineering attacks.
choices.d: By actively scanning web applications for known vulnerabilities.

questions.question: What is the benefit of using OWASP ZAP in the software development lifecycle?

choices.a: It helps developers write code more quickly.
choices.b: It prevents all types of security vulnerabilities.
choices.c: It identifies security issues early in development.
choices.d: It automatically fixes detected vulnerabilities.

438.definition: A vulnerability in software that is unpatched by the developer or an attack that exploits such a vulnerability.

questions.question: What is a zero-day vulnerability?

choices.a: A software flaw that has been exploited for zero days.
choices.b: A security vulnerability that has existed for a long time.
choices.c: A flaw in software that is known but not yet patched.
choices.d: A previously unknown and unpatched security vulnerability.

questions.question: Why are zero-day vulnerabilities considered dangerous?

choices.a: They are easy to patch and mitigate.
choices.b: They have no impact on the affected software.
choices.c: Attackers can exploit them before a fix is available.
choices.d: They only affect outdated software.

questions.question: What is the term 'zero-day' derived from?

choices.a: The fact that attackers strike at the zero hour of the day.
choices.b: The time zone where most cyberattacks originate.
choices.c: The number of days required to fix the vulnerability.
choices.d: The fact that developers have zero chance to fix it before it's exploited.

questions.question: Which of the following is a typical way to mitigate the risk of zero-day vulnerabilities?

choices.a: Using outdated software to avoid new vulnerabilities.
choices.b: Frequently applying security updates.
choices.c: Ignoring the vulnerabilities until they are patched.
choices.d: Announcing the vulnerabilities to the public immediately.

questions.question: How do security researchers discover and report zero-day vulnerabilities?

choices.a: By exploiting the vulnerabilities themselves.
choices.b: By keeping the vulnerabilities secret to avoid exploitation.
choices.c: By randomly guessing vulnerabilities in software.
choices.d: By responsibly disclosing them to the affected vendors.

439.definition: A method of sanitizing a drive by setting all bits to zero.

questions.question: What does the term 'zero-fill' refer to?

choices.a: Filling a storage device with zeros to securely erase data.
choices.b: Creating a hard drive partition with zero storage capacity.
choices.c: Filling a storage device with random data to improve performance.
choices.d: Creating a backup copy of data on a storage device.

questions.question: Why is zero-filling used for secure data erasure?

choices.a: To make data recovery faster and more efficient.
choices.b: To ensure that all data is permanently overwritten.
choices.c: To recover lost data from a corrupted storage device.
choices.d: To enhance the performance of the storage device.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common method of performing a zero-fill?

choices.a: Using a specialized erasure software.
choices.b: Physically destroying the storage device.
choices.c: Running a disk defragmentation tool.
choices.d: Creating multiple partitions on the storage device.

questions.question: What is the main benefit of zero-filling a storage device before disposal?

choices.a: It reduces the likelihood of hardware failures.
choices.b: It increases the resale value of the device.
choices.c: It allows for easy data recovery in the future.
choices.d: It prevents sensitive data from being recovered by unauthorized parties.

questions.question: What potential drawback should be considered when zero-filling a storage device?

choices.a: It can cause the device to overheat.
choices.b: It can permanently damage the device.
choices.c: It can reduce the storage device's performance.
choices.d: It can only be done on solid-state drives.
